metadata.title: Convert USD to EUR – Currency Converter
metadata.description: Convert US dollars to euros instantly with ECB-anchored rates, optional fee adjustments, and clear audit cues for quotes, invoices, and travel budgets.

fields.label: Amount in USD
fields.helpText: Enter the USD amount you want to convert; negatives are blocked for clean accounting.

fields.label: USD → EUR rate
fields.helpText: Auto-fetched from ECB; edit to match your bank’s quote (e.g., 0.92 means $1 = €0.92).

fields.label: Fee or spread (%)
fields.helpText: Optional markup or fee; set to 0 for pure mid-market.

fields.label: Rate date
fields.helpText: Pick a specific date or leave blank for the latest ECB reference.

introduction: Convert USD to EUR in one step with a rate field you control, ideal for travel budgets, invoices, and FX sanity checks.
We anchor guidance to ECB reference rates and federal economic data, while giving you an explicit fee input to mirror bank or card spreads.
Copy the gross and net euro values to keep quotes and audit trails transparent.
methodology: The converter multiplies your USD amount by the USD→EUR rate; we recommend using the ECB reference rate as a baseline and adjusting for your provider’s spread.
An optional fee percent applies a single-point markdown: EUR_after_fee = USD × rate × (1 – fee/100), so you can model bank, broker, or card costs.
Rates move intraday; note the timestamp and source (ECB, Federal Reserve H.10 / FRED DEXUSEU) when recording values for compliance or invoicing.
examples: $250 at 0.92 → €230.00 before fees; at a 1% fee it yields €227.70.
$1,200 payroll reimbursement at 0.915 → €1,098.00 before any card spread.
$50 travel cash at 0.90 with a 3% ATM fee → €43.65 after fee.

faqs.question: Which rate should I use?
faqs.answer: Use the ECB reference rate for a neutral mid-market anchor, then adjust the fee field to reflect your bank, broker, or card spread.

faqs.question: How often do rates change?
faqs.answer: Interbank rates move throughout the day. Refresh the rate field using your trusted source and note the time when logging or invoicing.

faqs.question: Why include a fee percent?
faqs.answer: Most providers add a spread. Applying a percent keeps quotes realistic and audit-ready compared to pure mid-market figures.

faqs.question: Can I remove the fee?
faqs.answer: Yes. Set the fee to 0 to see the mid-market conversion without spreads.

faqs.question: Is this suitable for compliance records?
faqs.answer: Yes, provided you record the rate source, timestamp, and any applied fee. ECB and Federal Reserve (H.10 / FRED DEXUSEU) are standard references.

summary: Single-field USD input with controllable rate and fee delivers both gross and net EUR outputs.
ECB and Federal Reserve references anchor rate selection; fee control mirrors real-world spreads.
Examples and FAQs emphasize timestamping and source tracking for invoices and compliance.

glossary.definition: A benchmark FX rate published by a trusted authority (e.g., ECB) used as a neutral mid-market anchor.
The markup or markdown applied by providers above the mid-market rate.
